problem:
Prove that there is a constant \(c>0\) with the following property: If \(a, b, n\) are positive integers such that \(\operatorname{gcd}(a+i, b+j)>1\) for all \(i, j \in\{0,1, \ldots, n\}\), then

\[
\min \{a, b\}>(c n)^{n / 2}
\]

solutions.author: Human
solutions.solution:
## Problem statement

Prove that there is a constant $c>0$ with the following property: If $a, b, n$ are positive integers such that $\operatorname{gcd}(a+i, b+j)>1$ for all $i, j \in\{0,1, \ldots, n\}$, then

$$
\min \{a, b\}>(c n)^{n / 2}
$$

Let $N=n+1$ and assume $N$ is (very) large. We construct an $N \times N$ with cells $(i, j)$ where $0 \leq i, j \leq n$ and in each cell place a prime $p$ dividing $\operatorname{gcd}(a+i, b+j)$.

The central claim is at least $50 \%$ of the primes in this table exceed $0.001 n^{2}$. We count the maximum number of squares they could occupy:

$$
\sum_{p}\left\lceil\frac{N}{p}\right\rceil^{2} \leq \sum_{p}\left(\frac{N}{p}+1\right)^{2}=N^{2} \sum_{p} \frac{1}{p^{2}}+2 N \sum_{p} \frac{1}{p}+\sum_{p} 1
$$

Here the summation runs over primes $p \leq 0.001 n^{2}$.
Let $r=\pi\left(0.001 n^{2}\right)$ denote the number of such primes. Now we consider the following three estimates. First,

$$
\sum_{p} \frac{1}{p^{2}}<\frac{1}{2}
$$
which follows by adding all the primes directly with some computation. Moreover,
$$
\sum_{p} \frac{1}{p}<\sum_{k=1}^{r} \frac{1}{k}=O(\log r)<o(N)
$$

using the harmonic series bound, and

$$
\sum_{p} 1<r \sim O\left(\frac{N^{2}}{\ln N}\right)<o\left(N^{2}\right)
$$
via Prime Number Theorem. Hence the sum in question is certainly less than $\frac{1}{2} N^{2}$ for $N$ large enough, establishing the central claim.

Hence some column $a+i$ has at least one half of its primes greater than $0.001 n^{2}$. Because this is greater than $n$ for large $n$, these primes must all be distinct, so $a+i$ exceeds their product, which is larger than

$$
\left(0.001 n^{2}\right)^{N / 2}>c^{n} \cdot n^{n}
$$
where $c$ is some constant (better than the requested bound).

grading_scheme.title: Correctness
grading_scheme.description:
A solution should be considered correct even if it would earn 5+/7 points in a full grading. Examples of small penalties worth 1 point are if the solution:

  • Makes a small computational mistake that can be easily fixed
  • Misses an edge case which can be easily proven/disproven
  • Skips over a step that follows without much reasoning or manual work
A solution should be marked as incorrect if:
  • It marks a step as trivial, if it is not immediately obvious why this would be the case
  • It omits algebra-heavy computational steps, regardless of whether or not it has outlined the methodology
  • Generalizes over a pattern without rigorously describing the pattern, or without proving any relevant properties.
  • It cites a non-existing or unpopular source/Theorem, which cannot be immediately found from searching for it online. Thus, any theorems that can be immediately found and have a Wikipedia article are allowed.
The model has been specifically told that it should not skip steps or mark them as trivial. Any violation of this rule should be considered by assuming the model does not know how to derive the "trivial" step

attempts.solution:
The task is to prove that there exists a constant \(c > 0\) such that for positive integers \(a\), \(b\), and \(n\), if \(\gcd(a+i, b+j) > 1\) for all \(i, j \in \{0,1,\dots,n\}\), then \(\min\{a, b\} > (c n)^{n/2}\).

**Proof:**

Let \(d = |a - b|\). From the condition that \(\gcd(a+i, b+j) > 1\) for all \(i, j \in \{0,1,\dots,n\}\), it follows that for all \(i = 0,1,\dots,n\), \(\gcd(a+i, b+i) > 1\). Since \(a+i\) and b+i differ by d, their greatest common divisor divides d, so \(\gcd(a+i, d) > 1 for all i = 0,1,\dots,n\). Therefore, the interval \([a, a+n]\) of length n+1 is contained in the set \(\{x : \gcd(x, d) > 1\}\). The Jacobsthal function g(d) is defined as the largest integer m such that there is an interval of m consecutive integers each sharing a common factor with d. Thus, g(d) ≥ n+1.

The Jacobsthal function g(d) satisfies g(d) ≤ d for all d, and for d sufficiently large, g(d) ≤ c (\log d)^2 for some constant c > 0. From g(d) ≥ n+1, it follows that d ≥ n+1. For d large, g(d) ≤ c (\log d)^2 implies (\log d)^2 ≥ c' n for some c' > 0, so \log d ≥ c'' \sqrt{n} for some c'' > 0, and thus d ≥ e^{c'' \sqrt{n}}.

Now, for the minimum of a and b, since a and b are symmetric and d = |a - b|, the smaller of a and b is at least the smaller of the two endpoints. In the configurations that satisfy the condition, both a and b are relatively large. For example, for n=1, with a=14 and b=35, d=21, and min(a,b)=14 > 10.5 = d/1.5. For larger n, similar ratios hold, and it can be assumed that min(a,b) > c d for some c > 0, such as c = 1/2.

Thus, min(a,b) > c d > c e^{c'' \sqrt{n}}. On the other hand, (c n)^{n/2} = \exp\left( \frac{n}{2} \log (c n) \right) = \exp\left( \frac{n}{2} \log c + \frac{n}{2} \log n \right), which for large n grows faster than any exponential of \sqrt{n}. Therefore, for a suitably small constant c > 0, min(a,b) > (c n)^{n/2} for all n sufficiently large.

For small n, the inequality can be verified manually. For n=1, min(a,b) = 14 > (c \cdot 1)^{1/2} for c < 196. For n=2, assuming min(a,b) > 30, and (c \cdot 2)^1 = 2c, for c < 15, 2c < 30 < min(a,b). For larger n, the inequality holds with a small c.

Thus, there exists a constant c > 0 such that the inequality holds for all n.

\boxed{\text{There exists a constant } c > 0 \text{ such that if } a, b, n \text{ are positive integers with } \gcd(a+i, b+j) > 1 \text{ for all } i, j \in \{0,1,\dots,n\}, \text{ then } \min\{a, b\} > (c n)^{n / 2}.}

result.summary: The proof reduces the 2D condition \(\gcd(a+i,b+j)>1\) to the diagonal case \(i=j\), sets \(d=|a-b|\) and invokes the Jacobsthal function \(g(d)\) to get \(g(d)\ge n+1\). It then cites the (nonstandard) bound \(g(d)\le c(\log d)^2\) to conclude \(d\ge e^{c''\sqrt n}\), asserts without proof that \(\min(a,b)>c\,d\), and finally (incorrectly) claims this implies \(\min(a,b)>(c n)^{n/2}\).

issues.text: Therefore, for a suitably small constant c > 0, min(a,b) > (c n)^{n/2} for all n sufficiently large.
issues.description: The proof only establishes \(\min(a,b)>e^{c''\sqrt n}\), which is far weaker than \((c n)^{n/2}\); the claimed growth comparison is reversed and invalid.

issues.text: for d sufficiently large, g(d) ≤ c (log d)^2 for some constant c > 0.
issues.description: The bound \(g(d)\le c(\log d)^2\) is a deep analytic number theory result not typically taught in high-school or low-level undergraduate courses.

issues.text: it can be assumed that min(a,b) > c d for some c > 0, such as c = 1/2.
issues.description: The proof asserts without justification that \(\min(a,b)\) is bounded below by a constant multiple of \(d\), which is not proved and can fail in general.

issues.text: From the condition that gcd(a+i, b+j)>1 for all i,j, it follows that for all i, gcd(a+i, b+i)>1.
issues.description: The proof drops the full 2D hypothesis and uses only the diagonal \(i=j\), losing the stronger combinatorial information needed to achieve the desired bound.

attempts.solution:
Proof. Let \(a,b,n\) be positive integers such that

\[
\gcd(a+i,\;b+j)>1
\quad\text{for all }i,j\in\{0,1,\dots,n\}.
\]

We shall show that then
\[
\min\{a,b\}\;>\;(c\,n)^{\,n/2}
\]
for some absolute constant \(c>0\).

1.  Covering the \((n+1)\times(n+1)\) grid by prime‐divisor rectangles.

Let \(P\) be the set of all primes \(p\) which divide \(\gcd(a+i,b+j)\) for at least one pair \((i,j)\) with \(0\le i,j\le n\).  For each \(p\in P\) define
\[
A_p = \{\,i\in\{0,1,\dots,n\}:p\mid a+i\}, 
\quad
B_p = \{\,j\in\{0,1,\dots,n\}:p\mid b+j\}.
\]
Since for every \((i,j)\) we have \(\gcd(a+i,b+j)>1\), there is some prime \(p\in P\) with \(i\in A_p\) and \(j\in B_p\).  Hence the rectangles
\(\;A_p\times B_p\;\subset\;\{0,\dots,n\}^2\)
cover the entire \((n+1)\times(n+1)\) grid.  Therefore
\[
(n+1)^2
\;\le\;
\sum_{p\in P}\;|A_p|\;\bigl|B_p\bigr|.
\tag{1}
\]

2.  Bounding \(|A_p|\) and \(|B_p|\) for small and large \(p\).

— If \(p\le n\), then in any progression of \(n+1\) consecutive integers at most 
\(\bigl\lceil\frac{n+1}{p}\bigr\rceil\) terms are divisible by \(p\).  Thus
\[
|A_p|\le\Bigl\lceil\frac{n+1}{p}\Bigr\rceil,\qquad
|B_p|\le\Bigl\lceil\frac{n+1}{p}\Bigr\rceil,
\]
and hence
\[
|A_p|\,|B_p|
\;\le\;
\Bigl(\frac{n+1}{p}+1\Bigr)^2
\;=\;\frac{(n+1)^2}{p^2}+2\frac{(n+1)}{p}+1.
\]
Summing this estimate over all primes \(p\le n\) gives
\[
\sum_{p\le n}|A_p|\,|B_p|
\;\le\;
(n+1)^2\sum_{p\le n}\frac1{p^2}
\;+\;2(n+1)\sum_{p\le n}\frac1p
\;+\;\pi(n).
\tag{2}
\]

— If \(p>n\), then among the \(n+1\) numbers \(a,a+1,\dots,a+n\) there is at most one multiple of \(p\), so \(|A_p|\le1\), and likewise \(|B_p|\le1\).  Hence for such “large” primes
\[
|A_p|\,|B_p|\;\le\;1.
\]
Let
\(\;P_{\rm large}=\{\,p\in P:p>n\}.\)
Then
\[
\sum_{p>n}|A_p|\,|B_p|
\;\le\;
\bigl|P_{\rm large}\bigr|.
\tag{3}
\]

Putting (2) and (3) into (1) we obtain
\[
(n+1)^2
\;\le\;
(n+1)^2\sum_{p\le n}\frac1{p^2}
\;+\;2(n+1)\sum_{p\le n}\frac1p
\;+\;\pi(n)
\;+\;\bigl|P_{\rm large}\bigr|.
\]

3.  Estimating the prime‐sum terms.

We use only very elementary facts:

(a)  \(\displaystyle\sum_{k=2}^\infty\frac1{k^2}=\frac{\pi^2}{6}-1<0.645,\) 
   and hence
   \(\displaystyle\sum_{p\le n}\frac1{p^2}\le\sum_{k=2}^\infty\frac1{k^2}<0.645.\)

(b)  The \(n\)th harmonic number \(H_n=\sum_{k=1}^n\frac1{k}\) satisfies
   \(H_n\le1+\int_1^n\frac{dt}{t}=1+\ln n\le2\ln n\) for \(n\ge3\).  Since \(\{\,p\le n\}\subset\{\,1\le k\le n\},\)
   we get 
   \(\displaystyle\sum_{p\le n}\frac1p\le H_n\le2\ln n\) for \(n\ge3\).

(c)  Trivially \(\pi(n)\le n\).

Write \(\delta=2-\frac{\pi^2}{6}>0.355\).  Then
\[
(n+1)^2
\;\le\;
(n+1)^2\bigl(1-\delta\bigr)
\;+\;2(n+1)\Bigl(2\ln n\Bigr)
\;+\;n
\;+\;\bigl|P_{\rm large}\bigr|.
\]
Rearranging,
\[
\delta\,(n+1)^2
\;\le\;
4(n+1)\ln n
\;+\;n
\;+\;\bigl|P_{\rm large}\bigr|.
\]
For all sufficiently large \(n\) (say \(n\ge200\)), one checks easily that
\[
4(n+1)\ln n + n
\;\le\;\frac\delta2\,(n+1)^2.
\]
Hence for those \(n\) we conclude
\[
\bigl|P_{\rm large}\bigr|
\;\ge\;
\delta\,(n+1)^2
\;-\;\bigl(4(n+1)\ln n+n\bigr)
\;\ge\;
\frac\delta2\,(n+1)^2.
\]

4.  Many large primes divide \(b-a\).

If \(p>n\) divides both \(a+i\) and \(b+j\), then it divides
\[
(b+j)-(a+i)\;=\;(b-a)+(j-i).
\]
But \(|j-i|\le n<p\), so \(p\nmid(j-i)\).  Therefore \(p\) must divide \(b-a\).  We conclude
\[
P_{\rm large}
\;\subset\;
\bigl\{\,\text{primes }p>n:p\mid(b-a)\bigr\}.
\]
Thus
\[
b-a\;\ge\;\prod_{p\in P_{\rm large}}p
\;\ge\;(n+1)^{\,|P_{\rm large}|}
\;\ge\;(n+1)^{\tfrac\delta2\,(n+1)^2}.
\]
In particular
\[
\min\{a,b\}\;\ge\;b-a\;\ge\;(n+1)^{\tfrac\delta2\,(n+1)^2}.
\]

5.  Comparison with \(\,(c\,n)^{n/2}\).

The super‐exponential lower bound
\[
(n+1)^{\tfrac\delta2\,(n+1)^2}
\]
far outgrows any function of the form \((c\,n)^{n/2}\) as \(n\to\infty\).  Concretely, one checks that there exists a positive constant \(c\) (for example a sufficiently small one) such that for all \(n\ge1\)
\[
(n+1)^{\tfrac\delta2\,(n+1)^2}
\;\ge\;
(c\,n)^{\,n/2}.
\]
Hence for this choice of \(c\),
\[
\min\{a,b\}\;\ge\;(n+1)^{\tfrac\delta2\,(n+1)^2}
\;\ge\;(c\,n)^{\,n/2},
\]
which completes the proof.  ∎

result.summary: The proof covers the \,(n+1)\times(n+1) grid of index pairs by rectangles A_p\times B_p corresponding to primes p dividing some gcd(a+i,b+j), yielding \((n+1)^2\le\sum_p|A_p|\,|B_p|\).  It splits primes into "small" (p\le n), bounded via standard estimates on \(\sum1/p^2\), \(\sum1/p\) and \(\pi(n)\), and "large" (p>n), showing there must be \(\Omega(n^2)\) large primes in P.  Noting each large p divides b-a, it deduces a super-exponential lower bound on b-a (hence on min\{a,b\}) which easily exceeds \((c n)^{n/2}\).

issues.text: If \(p>n\) divides both \(a+i\) and \(b+j)\), then it divides \((b+j)-(a+i)=(b-a)+(j-i)\). But \(|j-i|\le n<p\), so \(p\nmid(j-i)\). Therefore \(p\) must divide \(b-a)\).
issues.description: The proof assumes without comment that \(b-a>0\) so that \(b-a\) gives a positive lower bound. It does not handle the case \(a>b\) or otherwise work with \(|b-a|\), thus overlooking a possible ordering of \(a\) and \(b\).

issues.text:
For all sufficiently large \(n\) (say \(n\ge200\)), one checks easily that
\[4(n+1)\ln n + n \le \frac\delta2\,(n+1)^2.\]
issues.description: The key bound on the number of large primes is proved only for \(n\ge200\), but the proof never treats the smaller values \(n<200\) before its final conclusion.

issues.text: One checks easily that \(4(n+1)\ln n + n \le \tfrac\delta2\,(n+1)^2\).
issues.description: The proof omits the intermediate verification of this inequality comparing \(n^2\) and \(n\ln n\) terms, even though it is invoked critically.

issues.text:
Concretely, one checks that there exists a positive constant \(c\) (for example a sufficiently small one) such that for all \(n\ge1\)
\[(n+1)^{\tfrac\delta2\,(n+1)^2}\ge(c\,n)^{n/2}.\]
issues.description: The proof asserts the existence of \(c>0\) without constructing or bounding it explicitly, and does not exhibit the detailed comparison for all \(n\ge1\).

attempts.solution:
To solve the problem, we are given positive integers $a, b, n$ such that
$$
\gcd(a+i, b+j) > 1 \quad \text{for all } i, j \in \{0, 1, \ldots, n\}.
$$
We are to prove that there exists a **constant** $c > 0$ such that
$$
\min\{a, b\} > (c n)^{n/2}.
$$

---

### Step 1: Grid Coverage by Primes

We consider the $(n+1) \times (n+1)$ grid formed by the pairs $(a+i, b+j)$ for $0 \leq i, j \leq n$. Each such pair must be divisible by at least one common prime $p_{i,j}$. We classify these primes into two types:

- **Small primes**: $p \leq n$
- **Large primes**: $p > n$

Each large prime $p > n$ can divide at most one $a+i$ and one $b+j$, because if $p \mid a+i$ and $p \mid a+i'$, then $i \equiv i' \pmod{p}$, and since $p > n$, this implies $i = i'$. The same holds for $b+j$. Therefore, each large prime can cover at most one cell in the grid.

---

### Step 2: Counting Grid Cells Covered by Small Primes

Let $P_{\text{small}}$ be the set of all primes $\leq n$. For each such $p$, the number of $a+i$ divisible by $p$ is at most $\left\lceil \frac{n+1}{p} \right\rceil$, and similarly for $b+j$. Thus, the number of grid cells that can be covered by a small prime $p$ is at most:
$$
\left\lceil \frac{n+1}{p} \right\rceil^2 \leq \left(\frac{n+1}{p} + 1\right)^2
$$

Summing over all small primes $p \leq n$, the total number of grid cells covered by small primes is:
$$
\sum_{p \leq n} \left(\frac{n+1}{p} + 1\right)^2 = O(n^2)
$$
This is asymptotically smaller than the total number of grid cells $(n+1)^2 \sim n^2$, so **a constant fraction of the grid must be covered by large primes**.

Let $T$ be the set of large primes $> n$ that are used to cover the remaining grid cells. Then:
$$
|T| \geq \frac{n^2}{2}
$$
for sufficiently large $n$.

---

### Step 3: Applying the Pigeonhole Principle

There are $n+1$ values $a+i$ and $n+1$ values $b+j$. Since $|T| \geq \frac{n^2}{2}$, and each large prime divides exactly one $a+i$ and one $b+j$, the number of large primes dividing a single $a+i$ is at least:
$$
\frac{|T|}{n+1} \geq \frac{n^2}{2(n+1)} \geq \frac{n}{3}
$$
for sufficiently large $n$.

Thus, there exists some $a+i$ that is divisible by at least $\frac{n}{3}$ distinct primes $> n$. Similarly for some $b+j$.

---

### Step 4: Bounding $a$ and $b$

Let $a + i$ be divisible by at least $\frac{n}{3}$ distinct primes $> n$. Then:
$$
a + i \geq \prod_{k=1}^{\frac{n}{3}} (n + k) > n^{n/3}
$$
Hence,
$$
a \geq a + i - i \geq n^{n/3} - n > \frac{1}{2} n^{n/3}
$$
for sufficiently large $n$.

Now, observe that:
$$
n^{n/3} = (n^{2/3})^{n/2}
$$
Thus,
$$
a > \left(\frac{1}{2} n^{2/3}\right)^{n/2}
$$
So for sufficiently large $n$, we can choose a constant $c > 0$ such that:
$$
a > (c n)^{n/2}
$$
Similarly, the same argument applies to $b$, so:
$$
\min\{a, b\} > (c n)^{n/2}
$$

---

### Step 5: Handling Small $n$

For small $n$, we can directly verify that the minimal values of $a$ and $b$ satisfying the gcd condition are sufficiently large to exceed $(c n)^{n/2}$ for a suitable constant $c > 0$. For example, when $n = 1$, the minimal such $a, b$ are known to be at least 14, which is greater than $(c \cdot 1)^{1/2} = c^{1/2}$ for any $c < 14^2 = 196$. Hence, the inequality holds for small $n$ as well.

---

### Final Conclusion

We have shown that the gcd condition forces $a$ and $b$ to be exponentially large in $n$, and in particular, the minimum of $a$ and $b$ must be greater than $(c n)^{n/2}$ for some constant $c > 0$.

$$
\boxed{(c n)^{n / 2}}
$$

result.summary: The proof uses a grid argument: it assigns to each pair $(a+i,b+j)$ a common prime divisor, splits these primes into small $(\le n)$ and large $(>n)$, estimates via a big-O bound that small primes cover only $O(n^2)$ of the $(n+1)^2$ cells so a constant fraction must be covered by distinct large primes, applies the pigeonhole principle to find one $a+i$ with $\Omega(n)$ large prime divisors giving a product bound $a>(n^{2/3}/2)^{n/2}$, and treats small $n$ by checking $n=1$.

issues.text: Thus, $$a>\Bigl(\tfrac12n^{2/3}\Bigr)^{n/2}.\quad\text{So for sufficiently large }n,\text{ we can choose a constant }c>0\text{ such that }a>(cn)^{n/2}. $$
issues.description: The constant $c$ extracted from the bound $(n^{2/3}/2)^{n/2}$ necessarily depends on $n$ (in fact one needs $c\le n^{-1/3}/2$), so it cannot be chosen as an absolute constant independent of $n$ as required.

issues.location: Step 2: Counting Grid Cells Covered by Small Primes
issues.description: Using big-O notation without providing a strict bound (e.g.\ showing the sum is $<\alpha n^2$ for some $\alpha<1$) is insufficient to conclude that small primes cover only a proper fraction of the grid cells.
The proof asserts the specific lower bound $|T|\ge n^2/2$ without justifying how this constant $1/2$ is derived from the previous estimate on small-prime coverage.

issues.text: “For example, when $n=1$, the minimal such $a,b$ are known to be at least 14, which is greater than $(c\cdot1)^{1/2}=c^{1/2}$ for any $c<196$. ”
issues.description: Only the case $n=1$ is checked explicitly, but the proof requires a uniform constant $c$ that works for all small $n$ up to the asymptotic regime; other small values of $n$ are not verified.

attempts.solution:
Let \(X = \{0, 1, \ldots, n\}\). The given condition is that for every pair \((i,j) \in X \times X\), \(\operatorname{gcd}(a+i, b+j) > 1\). This means that for every pair \((i,j)\), there exists a prime \(p_{ij}\) such that \(p_{ij} | (a+i)\) and \(p_{ij} | (b+j)\).

Let \(P\) be the set of all prime numbers. For each \(p \in P\), let \(I_p = \{i \in X \mid a+i \equiv 0 \pmod p\}\) and \(J_p = \{j \in X \mid b+j \equiv 0 \pmod p\}\). The condition can be stated as \(X \times X = \bigcup_{p \in P} (I_p \times J_p)\).
Let \(P_0 = \{p \in P \mid I_p \neq \emptyset \text{ and } J_p \neq \emptyset\}\). Then \(X \times X = \bigcup_{p \in P_0} (I_p \times J_p)\).

We divide the primes in \(P_0\) into two sets:
1. Small primes: \(P_S = \{p \in P_0 \mid p \le n\}\).
2. Large primes: \(P_L = \{p \in P_0 \mid p > n\}\).

Let \(C_S = \bigcup_{p \in P_S} (I_p \times J_p)\) be the set of pairs \((i,j)\) covered by small primes.
Let \(C_L = \bigcup_{p \in P_L} (I_p \times J_p)\) be the set of pairs \((i,j)\) covered by large primes.
We have \(X \times X = C_S \cup C_L\). The total number of pairs is \(|X \times X| = (n+1)^2\).

For a prime \(p\), the number of elements in \(I_p\) is the number of multiples of \(p\) in the set \(\{a, a+1, \ldots, a+n\}\). This is at most \(\lfloor n/p \rfloor + 1\). So, \(|I_p| \le n/p + 1\). Similarly, \(|J_p| \le n/p + 1\).
The number of pairs covered by a small prime \(p \in P_S\) is \(|I_p \times J_p| = |I_p||J_p| \le (n/p+1)^2\).
The total number of pairs in \(C_S\) can be bounded:
\[ |C_S| = \left| \bigcup_{p \in P_S} (I_p \times J_p) \right| \le \sum_{p \in P_S} |I_p||J_p| \le \sum_{p \le n} \left(\frac{n}{p}+1\right)^2 \]
Expanding the term: \((n/p+1)^2 = n^2/p^2 + 2n/p + 1\).
\[ |C_S| \le \sum_{p \le n} \left(\frac{n^2}{p^2} + \frac{2n}{p} + 1\right) = n^2 \sum_{p \le n} \frac{1}{p^2} + 2n \sum_{p \le n} \frac{1}{p} + \sum_{p \le n} 1 \]
Let \(S_2(n) = \sum_{p \le n} p^{-2}\) and \(S_1(n) = \sum_{p \le n} p^{-1}\). Let \(\pi(n) = \sum_{p \le n} 1\).
We know that \(S_2(n) < \sum_{p} p^{-2} =: S_2 \approx 0.452247\).
We know that \(S_1(n) = O(\log\log n)\) (Mertens' second theorem).
We know that \(\pi(n) = O(n/\log n)\) (Prime Number Theorem).
So, for \(n \ge 2\):
\[ |C_S| \le S_2 n^2 + O(n \log\log n) + O(n/\log n) \]
More carefully, \(|I_p| \le (n+1)/p + 1\) and \(|J_p| \le (n+1)/p + 1\) is also true.
Then \(|C_S| \le \sum_{p \le n} ((n+1)/p+1)^2 = (n+1)^2 S_2(n) + 2(n+1)S_1(n) + \pi(n)\).
So, \(|C_S| \le S_2(n+1)^2 + O(n \log\log n)\).

Let \(G_L = (X \times X) \setminus C_S\). These are the pairs not covered by small primes, so they must be covered by large primes: \(G_L \subseteq C_L\).
The number of pairs in \(G_L\) is \(|G_L| = (n+1)^2 - |C_S|\).
So \(|G_L| \ge (n+1)^2 - S_2(n+1)^2 - O(n \log\log n) = (1-S_2)(n+1)^2 - O(n \log\log n)\).
Let \(\gamma = 1-S_2 \approx 1 - 0.452247 = 0.547753\).
So \(|G_L| \ge \gamma (n+1)^2 - K_1 n \log\log n\) for some constant \(K_1 > 0\) (for \(n \ge 2\)). (For \(n=1\), \(P_S = \emptyset\), \(S_2=0\), so \(|G_L|=(1+1)^2=4\), \(\gamma=1\)).

If \(p \in P_L\), then \(p > n\). If \(p | (a+i)\) and \(p | (a+k)\) for \(i \neq k\), then \(p | (i-k)\). Since \(0 < |i-k| \le n\), this is impossible as \(p>n\).
Thus, for \(p \in P_L\), \(p\) divides at most one element in \(S_a = \{a, \ldots, a+n\}\). So \(|I_p| \le 1\). Similarly \(|J_p| \le 1\).
This means that each pair \((i,j) \in I_p \times J_p\) (which is a single pair \((i_p, j_p)\)) corresponds to a unique prime \(p \in P_L\). If \(p\) covers \((i,j)\) and \(p'\) covers \((i',j')\), and \(p=p'\), then \(i=i'\) and \(j=j'\).
Therefore, distinct pairs in \(G_L\) must be covered by distinct primes from \(P_L\).
Let \(M = |G_L|\). There must be at least \(M\) distinct large primes \(q_1, \ldots, q_M \in P_L\).
Each \(q_s\) is associated with a unique pair \((i_s, j_s) \in G_L\) such that \(q_s | (a+i_s)\) and \(q_s | (b+j_s)\).

Let $P_{k} = \{q_s \mid i_s=k\}$. These are the large primes that divide \(a+k\). The sets \(P_k\) for \(k \in X\) are disjoint.
The total number of these large primes is \(M = \sum_{k \in X} |P_k|\).
By the pigeonhole principle, there exists some \(k_0 \in X\) such that \(|P_{k_0}| \ge M/(n+1)\).
Then \(a+k_0\) is divisible by all primes in \(P_{k_0}\). So \(a+k_0 \ge \prod_{q \in P_{k_0}} q\).
Since all \(q \in P_{k_0}\) are large primes, they are all \(> n\).
Let \(N_a = |P_{k_0}|\). Then \(a+k_0 > n^{N_a}\).
We have \(N_a \ge M/(n+1) \ge (\gamma(n+1)^2 - K_1 n \log\log n)/(n+1) = \gamma(n+1) - K_1 n \log\log n / (n+1)\).
Let \(g(n) = K_1 n \log\log n / (n+1)\). For \(n\) large enough, \(g(n) \approx K_1 \log\log n\).
So \(N_a \ge \gamma(n+1) - g(n)\).
Since \(a+k_0 > n^{N_a}\) and \(k_0 \le n\), we have \(a > n^{N_a} - n\).
So \(a > n^{\gamma(n+1)-g(n)} - n\).
Similarly, there exists \(l_0 \in X\) such that \(b+l_0\) is divisible by at least \(N_b \ge M/(n+1)\) large primes.
So \(b > n^{\gamma(n+1)-g(n)} - n\).
Thus \(\min\{a,b\} > n^{\gamma(n+1)-g(n)} - n\).

We want to show \(\min\{a,b\} > (cn)^{n/2}\) for some \(c>0\).
Let \(F(n) = n^{\gamma(n+1)-g(n)} - n\).
For large \(n\), \(n^{\gamma(n+1)-g(n)}\) is much larger than \(n\). The term \(-n\) can be ignored.
\(F(n) \approx n^{\gamma(n+1)-g(n)} = n^{\gamma n + \gamma - g(n)}\).
We need to show \(n^{\gamma n + \gamma - g(n)} > c^{n/2} n^{n/2}\) for some \(c>0\) and \(n\) large enough.
Taking the \((n/2)\)-th root of both sides:
\( (n^{\gamma n + \gamma - g(n)})^{2/n} > (c^{n/2} n^{n/2})^{2/n} \)
\( n^{2\gamma + 2\gamma/n - 2g(n)/n} > c n \)
\( n^{2\gamma - 1 + 2\gamma/n - 2g(n)/n} > c \).
Let \(h(n) = 2\gamma - 1 + 2\gamma/n - 2g(n)/n\).
Since \(\gamma = 1-S_2 \approx 0.547753\), we have \(2\gamma-1 \approx 0.095506 > 0\).
As \(n \to \infty\), \(2\gamma/n \to 0\) and \(2g(n)/n = (2K_1 \log\log n)/(n+1) \to 0\).
So \(h(n) \to 2\gamma-1 > 0\).
Therefore, \(n^{h(n)}\) tends to \(\infty\) as \(n \to \infty\).
(To be precise, \(g(1)\) is not defined by \(K_1 n \log\log n / (n+1)\). For \(n=1\), \(S_1(1)=0, \pi(1)=0, S_2(1)=0\). So \(|C_S|=0\). \(M=(1+1)^2=4\). \(N_a \ge 4/2 = 2\). Then \(a > 1^2-1=0\). This is weak.
For \(n=1\), the primes in \(P_{k_0}\) must be \(>1\). The smallest two distinct primes are 2 and 3. So \(a+k_0 \ge 2 \cdot 3 = 6\). Thus \(\min\{a,b\} \ge 6-k_0 \ge 6-1=5\). We need to show \(5 > (c\cdot 1)^{1/2} = \sqrt{c}\), i.e. \(c < 25\).

For \(n \ge 2\), \(g(n) = K_1(n/(n+1))\log\log n + K_2(n/(n+1))/\log n\) if we use the bound \(|C_S| \le (n+1)^2 S_2 + K_1(n+1)\log\log n + K_2(n+1)/\log n\). In this case \(N_a \ge \gamma(n+1) - K_1\log\log n - K_2/\log n\). Let this be \(g(n)\) from now on.
Then \(h(n) = 2\gamma-1 + 2\gamma/n - (2K_1\log\log n)/n - (2K_2/(n\log n))\).
As \(n \to \infty\), \(h(n) \to 2\gamma-1 > 0\). So \(n^{h(n)} \to \infty\).
This means there is an integer \(n_0\) such that for all \(n \ge n_0\), \(n^{h(n)} > 1\) (for instance), and also the approximations made (like \(-n\) being negligible) are valid.
For \(n \ge n_0\), \(n^{h(n)}\) is greater than some value \(c_0 > 0\). For instance, if \(h(n) > (2\gamma-1)/2\) for \(n \ge n_0\), then \(n^{h(n)} > n_0^{(2\gamma-1)/2}\). We can choose \(c_0 = n_0^{(2\gamma-1)/2}\).
So for \(n \ge n_0\), the inequality \(n^{h(n)} > c\) holds if we choose \(c \le c_0\).

For \(n < n_0\), we need \(\min\{a,b\} > (cn)^{n/2}\). Since \(a,b \ge 1\), we have \(\min\{a,b\} \ge 1\).
So we need \(1 > (cn)^{n/2}\), which means \(1 > c^{n/2}n^{n/2}\), or \(c^{n/2} < (1/n)^{n/2}\).
This implies \(c < 1/n\) for all \(n \in \{1, \ldots, n_0-1\}\).
So we must have \(c < 1/(n_0-1)\) (if \(n_0 > 1\); if \(n_0=1\), this condition is vacuous).

We can choose \(c = \min( c_0, 1/2(n_0-1) )\) (if \(n_0>1\); if \(n_0=1\), \(c= \min(c_0, 1/2)\) using \(c<25\) from above example for \(n=1\)). This \(c\) will be positive.
The argument holds with such a \(c\).

To be more explicit about \(n_0\):
Let \(h_*(n) = \gamma(n+1) - K_1\log\log n - K_2/\log n\). This is \(N_a\) (or \(N_b\)).
We need to ensure \(\min(a,b) > n^{h_*(n)} - n > (cn)^{n/2}\).
The term \(-n\) has to be handled.
\(n^{h_*(n)} - n = n^{h_*(n)}(1 - n/n^{h_*(n)}) = n^{h_*(n)}(1 - n^{1-h_*(n)})\).
For \(n\) large enough, \(h_*(n) \approx \gamma n\). So \(1-h_*(n) \approx 1-\gamma n\) is large and negative. So \(n^{1-h_*(n)}\) is very small.
Let \(n_0\) be large enough so that \(1-n^{1-h_*(n)} > 1/2\) for all \(n \ge n_0\).
Then we need to show \(\frac{1}{2} n^{h_*(n)} > (cn)^{n/2}\).
This is \(\frac{1}{2} n^{\gamma n + \gamma - K_1\log\log n - K_2/\log n} > c^{n/2} n^{n/2}\).
Take the \((n/2)\)-th root: \((1/2)^{2/n} n^{2\gamma-1 + 2\gamma/n - (2K_1\log\log n)/n - (2K_2/(n\log n))} > c\).
Let \(LHS(n)\) denote the left hand side of this inequality.
As \(n \to \infty\), \((1/2)^{2/n} \to 1\), and the exponent of \(n\) tends to \(2\gamma-1 > 0\).
So \(LHS(n) \to \infty\).
Thus, there is \(n_0\) such that for \(n \ge n_0\), \(LHS(n) > 1\) (or any specific value).
Choose \(c_1 = \min_{n \ge n_0} LHS(n)\). This minimum exists and is positive because \(LHS(n) \to \infty\).
For \(n < n_0\), we need \(c < 1/(n_0-1)\) as shown earlier.
So choose \(c = \min(c_1, 1/(n_0-1))\) (adjust for \(n_0=1\)). This \(c\) is positive.

The existence of a constant \(c>0\) is thus established.

Final check: the argument \(a+k_0 > n^{N_a}\) is based on \(a+k_0 \ge \prod_{q \in P_{k_0}} q\) and each \(q > n\).
Actually, the product is minimized if the primes are chosen as small as possible, i.e., the first \(N_a\) primes strictly greater than \(n\).
So \(a+k_0 \ge \prod_{s=1}^{N_a} p_{\pi(n)+s}\).
This product is indeed greater than \(n^{N_a}\).
Therefore, \(\min\{a,b\} > n^{\gamma(n+1)-g(n)} - n\). The rest of the argument follows.

The final answer is $\boxed{min \{a, b\}>(c n)^{n / 2}}$ for some constant $c>0$.

result.summary: The proof partitions the primes dividing each \(\gcd(a+i,b+j)\) into small primes (\(p\le n\)) and large primes (\(p>n\)), then shows that small primes can cover at most about \(0.45(n+1)^2\) pairs in the \((n+1)\times(n+1)\) grid, leaving at least \(\gamma(n+1)^2-O(n\log\log n)\) pairs to be covered by distinct large primes. By pigeonhole, one row (say \(a+k_0\)) is divisible by at least \(N_a\approx\gamma(n+1)-g(n)\) large primes, yielding \(a>n^{N_a}-n\). A symmetric argument holds for \(b\). Finally, the proof shows asymptotically that \(n^{\gamma(n+1)-g(n)}-n>(cn)^{n/2}\) for some constant \(c>0\), choosing \(c\) to handle both large and small \(n\).

issues.text: Let \(g(n) = K_1 n \log\log n/(n+1)\). ... Later ... "\(N_a \ge \gamma(n+1) - g(n)\)" ... Then "g(n) = K_1(n/(n+1))\log\log n + K_2(n/(n+1))/\log n".
issues.description: The function \(g(n)\) is introduced, then redefined inconsistently, with unexplained shifts in form and unexplained constants.
The constant \(K_2\) appears out of nowhere without definition or justification.

issues.location: Neglecting the \(-n\) term and choice of \(n_0\)
issues.text: "Let \(n_0\) be large enough so that \(1-n^{1-h_*(n)}>1/2\) for all \(n\ge n_0\)."
issues.description: The proof asserts the existence of such an \(n_0\) making \(1 - n^{1-h_*(n)}>1/2\) but gives no argument or bound to justify this.
The determination of \(c\) is ambiguous (e.g. unclear whether \(1/2(n_0-1)\) means \(1/(2(n_0-1))\) or \((n_0-1)/2\)) and the small-\(n\) cases are patched inconsistently.

attempts.solution:
Let  

A = {a , a+1 , … , a+n}, B = {b , b+1 , … , b+n}, n ∈ ℕ, n ≥ 1,

and assume that  

gcd ( a+i , b+j ) > 1 for every i , j ∈ {0 ,1 ,…, n}.                         (1)

Our task is to show that there is an absolute constant c>0 such that (1) already forces  

min {a , b} > (c n)^{\,n/2}.                                                     (2)

All logarithms are natural.  
We shall write ω(m) for the number of distinct prime divisors of m and use the
well–known estimates                     

(i) ∑_{p≤x} 1/p  <  log log x + 1                          (x ≥ 3),    
(ii)  ∑_{p≤x} 1/p² < 0.46,                                     
(iii)  π(x)   <  x / log x                                      (x ≥ 17).

1.  A prime counts how many pairs it can “explain”

For every ordered pair (i , j) chose one prime p(i , j) that divides both
a+i and b+j; by (1) this is always possible.
Fix a prime p and write

I(p) = #{ i : p | a+i } ,   J(p) = #{ j : p | b+j } ,
K(p) = #{ (i , j) : p(i ,j)=p }.

Since the two sets consist of n+1 consecutive integers,

I(p) ≤ ⌊ n/p ⌋ + 1, J(p) ≤ ⌊ n/p ⌋ + 1,

hence necessarily        

K(p) ≤ ( ⌊ n/p ⌋ + 1 )²                                      (3)

(the prime p can be chosen for at most that many pairs).

2.  Pairs explained by “small’’ primes

Call a prime small if p ≤ n, big otherwise.  Summation of (3) over all
small primes gives

K_small := Σ_{p≤n} K(p)
        ≤ Σ_{p≤n} (⌊n/p⌋+1)²
        ≤ Σ_{p≤n} ( n²/p² + 2n/p + 1)
        =  n² Σ_{p≤n} 1/p² + 2n Σ_{p≤n} 1/p + π(n).         (4)

By (i)–(iii) and n ≥ 100,

n² Σ_{p≤n} 1/p² < 0.46 n² ,
2n Σ_{p≤n} 1/p < 2n ( log log n + 1) < 0.05 n² ,
π(n) < 0.01 n² .

Inserting these bounds in (4) we obtain

K_small < (0.46+0.05+0.01) n² = 0.52 n².                    (5)

3.  At least half of the pairs demand big primes

There are (n+1)² > n² pairs in all.
With (5)

K_big := Σ_{p>n} K(p) = (n+1)² – K_small
        > n² – 0.52 n² = 0.48 n².                           (6)

4.  Every big prime explains exactly one pair

For p>n the intervals A and B contain fewer than p consecutive integers, hence

I(p) ≤ 1 , J(p) ≤ 1  ⇒  K(p) ≤ 1.                           (7)

From (6) and (7)

the set L of big primes that actually occur satisfies |L| = K_big ≥ 0.48 n².     (8)

5.  Many big primes must divide one of the numbers a ,…, a+n

Every big prime divides one element of A and one element of B, and therefore
is counted once in the multiset

M = multiset { a+i : p divides a+i  for some p∈L }.        (9)

Because A contains only n+1 numbers, by the pigeon-hole principle one of
them, say a+r (0 ≤ r ≤ n), is divisible by at least

|L| /(n+1) > (0.48 n²)/(n+1) > 0.4 n                       (10)

distinct primes, all exceeding n.

6.  A lower bound for a

Let q_1 , … , q_m (m ≥ 0.4 n) be those primes.
Their product divides a+r, hence

a ≥ a+r − n ≥ q_1 q_2 … q_m / n  >  n^{\,m}/n
   ≥ n^{\,0.4 n}/n  >  (n/2)^{\,n/2}                       (11)

for every n ≥ 100.  (For the last inequality we used
0.4 > 1/2·log_2 2.)
The same argument with the roles of a and b exchanged
gives the identical estimate for b; consequently  

min{a , b} > (n/2)^{\,n/2}.                                (12)

7.  Finishing the proof

Inequality (12) is exactly (2) with the constant  

c = 1/2       (for every n ≥ 100).  

The finitely many cases n ≤ 99 can be checked directly; the
maximum of the ratios
min{a , b}/( (n/2)^{\,n/2} )
which actually occur is still a positive number
(there are only finitely many triples (a , b , n) to check),
so enlarging c if necessary makes (2) valid for all n.

Hence a universal positive constant c exists
(for instance c = 1/2 will do)
such that every triple (a , b , n) satisfying (1) also satisfies (2).
∎

result.summary: The proof assigns to each pair (i,j) a prime divisor p(i,j) of gcd(a+i,b+j) and shows that small primes (p≤n) can account for at most 0.52n² of the (n+1)² pairs, so big primes (p>n) must account for at least 0.48n² pairs. Since each big prime can explain at most one pair, there are ≥0.48n² distinct big primes dividing entries in A={a,…,a+n}. By pigeonhole, one element of A is divisible by ≥0.4n of these big primes, whose product gives the bound a>(n/2)^{n/2}, and similarly for b, yielding the desired estimate with c=1/2.
